Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: An innovative virtual reality platform that accurately and rapidly assesses meaningful brain function outside the lab
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project lies not only with athletes, but with the 3 million Americans who suffer a traumatic brain injury each year, and the 40+ million more who are concerned about dementia and seek a way to measure their brain health. Current solutions (typically available only at facilities with trained professionals) assess only significant health changes to cognition. In contrast, our solution provides an affordable, reliable way to measure brain health and to monitor changes after treatment, training, and rehabilitation. Thus, it will be an excellent tool other companies can use to assess various interventions aimed at affecting brain function. The "quantified self" market sells technologies (wearables, DNA tests, software) that collect data to inform and guide health and self-improvement. The total addressable global market is estimated at ~$19B for 2019. The initial target market of customers are those seeking a competitive athletic edge by measuring, tracking, and training cognitive abilities such as reaction time, decision-making, and multitasking. These customers are coaches in high schools, colleges, and high-performance gyms across the US.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will address the need to combine and harness the power of eye-, hand-, and head-tracking instruments, virtual reality, and cognitive neuroscience to accurately measure and monitor brain function. This Phase I SBIR project will complete four technical objectives: (1) to develop a highly controlled testing environment that can accurately measure the time users (athletes) spend on detecting, processing, and acting on different cognitive tasks; (2) to develop software that can collect reliable data from naturalistic inputs; (3) to develop a set of tasks that users can complete within 30 minutes and that will generate sufficient data for analysis; and (4) quickly process, summarize, and contextualize the collected data and report meaningful results to the athletes and their trainers. Successful completion of these objectives will realize a first-of-its-kind product that provides meaningful insight into the brain with laboratory-quality cognitive assessment in a real-world context.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NeuroTrainer's Phase I work established the technical and commercial feasibility of NeuroScore(TM). The platform combines and harnesses the power of hand-tracking instruments, virtual reality, and cognitive neuroscience to accurately measure and monitor brain function of athletes. The platform successfully teaches athletes to respond to complex visual stimuli in a wide field of view. These measures correlate to in-game performance and assist athletic staff in scouting and player development activities. We developed a first-of-its-kind product that provides meaningful insight into the brain with laboratory-quality cognitive assessment in a real-world context.

The SBIR Phase I project explored the feasibility of our product both technically and commercially. We successfully demonstrated the ability to measure athletes quickly and reliably, with more than 95% of users able to complete the assessment battery in less than 30 minutes with greater than 0.90 test/re-test reliability (median test-retest reliability across five measures was 0.9301). We successfully created an athletic hand-reaching input for our product, and customer feedback has been strongly positive towards this functionality. We developed several high-impact data analyses and visualizations that also have received strongly favorable customer responses. The outcome of this project was the completion of a product that provides customers with the ability to easily record high-quality measurement of athletes? cognitive abilities and see the results in an online analytics dashboard. This dashboard provides data visualization which promotes comparison of athletes and track changes over time.

We learned from the market that our current product is sufficient to sell to the more progressive professional sports franchises. So far this year we have successfully sold NeuroTrainer to professional teams and minor league affiliates in the MLB, NBA, NHL, MLS, and NCAA. We now must continue responding to customer feedback to capture more customers in this market. We currently have more than a dozen professional sports franchises actively evaluating our product. Importantly, a significant portion of this traction has come from word-of-mouth and recommendations from customers to prospective customers. We feel that this fact gives us a strong indication of future growth.

Our vision is that teams and athletes will consider NeuroScore as being responsible for bringing objective, hard science to the world of player development, scouting, and drafting.

The broader impact for this work is in healthcare applications. As we acquire a large user base, we plan to explore machine learning to develop further insights to better measure and train both cognitive performance and health. This technology holds the promise to measure and track cognitive ability in populations with cognitive decline, concussion, ADHD, and vision loss. We believe that measuring your cognitive health will become similar to stepping on a scale to know your weight. Additionally, the technology can provide a broader impact in healthcare populations for training, rehabilitation, and other clinical interventions.

 


Last Modified: 08/08/2019
Modified by: Jeff Nyquist
